resources.string: A unit of length equal to 0.3048 metres (standard name ft).
A unit of length equal to 0.9144 metres (standard name yd).
A unit of length equal to 0.0254 metres (standard name in).
A unit of length equal to 1609.344 metres (standard name mi).
A unit of length equal to 1852.0 metres (standard name nmi).
A unit of length equal to 1E-10 metres (standard name Å).
A unit of length equal to the average distance from the center of the Earth to the center of the Sun (standard name ua).
A unit of length equal to the distance that light travels in one year through a vacuum (standard name ly).

A unit of length equal to the distance at which a star would appear to shift its position by one arcsecond over the course the time (about 3 months) in which the Earth moves a distance of one Astronomical Unit in the direction perpendicular to the direction to the star (standard name pc).
A unit of length equal to 0.013837 inches exactly (standard name pt).
A unit of length equal to 1/72 INCH (standard name pixel). It is the American point rounded to an even 1/72 inch.
Equivalent to one Pixel
A unit of duration equal to 60 seconds (standard name min).
A unit of duration equal to 60 minutes (standard name h).
A unit of duration equal to 24 hours (standard name d).
A unit of duration equal to 7 days (standard name week).
A unit of duration equal to 365 days, 5 hours, 49 minutes, and 12 seconds (standard name year).
A unit of duration equal to one twelfth of a year (standard name month).

A unit of duration equal to the time required for a complete rotation of the earth in reference to any star or to the vernal equinox at the meridian, equal to 23 hours, 56 minutes, 4.09 seconds (standard name day_sidereal).
A unit of duration equal to one complete revolution of the earth about the sun, relative to the fixed stars, or 365 days, 6 hours, 9 minutes, 9.54 seconds (standard name year_sidereal).
A unit of duration equal to 365 days (standard name year_calendar).
A unit of mass equal to 1/12 the mass of the carbon-12 atom (standard name u).
A unit of mass equal to the mass of the electron (standard name me).
A unit of mass equal to 453.59237 grams (avoirdupois pound, standard name lb).
A unit of mass equal to 1/16 pound (standard name oz).
A unit of mass equal to 2000 pounds (short ton, standard name ton_us).
A unit of mass equal to 2240 pounds (long ton, standard name ton_uk).
A unit of mass equal to 1000 kilograms (metric ton, standard name t).
A unit of electric charge equal to the charge on one electron (standard name e).
A unit of electric charge equal to equal to the product of Avogadro\'s number and the charge (1e) on a single electron (standard name Fd).
A unit of electric charge which exerts a force of one dyne on an equal charge at a distance of one centimeter (standard name Fr).
A unit of temperature equal to 5/9 °K (standard name °R).
A unit of temperature equal to degree Rankine minus 459.67 °R (standard name °F).
A unit of angle equal to a full circle or 2PI radian (standard name rev).
A unit of angle equal to 1/360 revolution (standard name °).
A unit of angle equal to 1/60 degree angle (standard name ′).
A unit of angle equal to 1/60 minute angle (standard name ").
A unit of angle equal to 0.01 radian (standard name centiradian).
A unit of angle measure equal to 1/400 revolution (standard name grade).
A unit of velocity expressing the number of international miles per hour (abbreviation mph).
A unit of velocity expressing the number of kilometres per HOUR hour.
A unit of velocity expressing the number of nautical miles per hour (abbreviation kn).
A unit of velocity to express the speed of an aircraft relative to the speed of sound (standard name Mach).
A unit of velocity relative to the speed of light (standard name c).
A unit of acceleration equal to the gravity at the earth\'s surface (standard name grav).
A unit of area equal to 100 m² (standard name a).
A unit of area equal to 100 are (standard name ha).
A unit of data amount equal to 8 bit (Binary Term, standard name byte).
Equivalent BYTE
A unit of electric charge equal to the centimeter-gram-second electromagnetic unit of magnetomotive force, equal to 10/4 PIampere-turn (standard name Gi).
A unit of energy equal to 1E-7 J (standard name erg).
A unit of energy equal to one electron-volt (standard name eV, also recognized keV, MeV, GeV).
A unit of illuminance equal to 1E4 Lx (standard name La).
A unit of magnetic flux equal 1E-8 Wb (standard name Mx).
A unit of magnetic flux density equal 1000 A/m (standard name G).
A unit of force equal to 1E-5 N (standard name dyn).
A unit of force equal to 9.80665 N (standard name kgf).
A unit of force equal to Pound·G (standard name lbf).
A unit of power equal to the power required to raise a mass of 75 kilograms at a velocity of 1 meter per second (metric, standard name hp).
A unit of pressure equal to the average pressure of the Earth\'s atmosphere at sea level (standard name atm).
A unit of pressure equal to 100 kPa (standard name bar).
A unit of pressure equal to the pressure exerted at the Earth\'s surface by a column of mercury 1 millimeter high (standard name mmHg).
A unit of pressure equal to the pressure exerted at the Earth\'s surface by a column of mercury 1 inch high (standard name inHg).
A unit of radiation dose absorbed equal to a dose of 0.01 joule of energy per kilogram of mass (J/kg) (standard name rd).
A unit of radiation dose effective equal to 0.01 Sv (standard name rem).
A unit of radioctive activity equal to the activity of a gram of radium (standard name Ci).
A unit of radioctive activity equal to 1 million radioactive disintegrations per second (standard name Rd).
A unit of solid angle equal to 4 PI steradians (standard name sphere).
A unit of volume equal to one cubic decimeter (default label L, also recognized µL, mL, cL, dL).
Equivalent to LITRE (American spelling).
A unit of volume equal to one cubic inch (in³).
A unit of volume equal to one US gallon, Liquid Unit. The U.S. liquid gallon is based on the Queen Anne or Wine gallon occupying 231 cubic inches (standard name gal).
A unit of volume equal to one US quart, Liquid Unit.
A unit of volume equal to one US pint, Liquid Unit.
A unit of volume equal to 1 / 128 fluid gallon (standard name oz_fl).
A unit of volume equal to one US dry gallon. (standard name gallon_dry_us).
A unit of volume equal to one US dry quart.
A unit of volume equal to one US dry pint.
A unit of volume equal to 4.546 09 LITRE (standard name gal_uk).
A unit of volume equal to 1 / 160 gallon (uk) (standard name oz_fl_uk).
A unit of dynamic viscosity equal to 1 g/(cm·s) (cgs unit).
A unit of kinematic viscosity equal to 1 cm²/s (cgs unit).
A unit used to measure the ionizing ability of radiation (standard name Roentgen).
Default constructor (prevents this class from being instantiated).

The base unit for luminous intensity quantities (cd). The candela is the luminous intensity, in a given direction, of a source that emits monochromatic radiation of frequency 540 × 1012 hertz and that has a radiant intensity in that direction of 1/683 watt per steradian

The base unit for thermodynamic temperature quantities (K). The kelvin is the 1/273.16th of the thermodynamic temperature of the triple point of water. It is named after the Scottish mathematician and physicist William Thomson 1st Lord Kelvin (1824-1907)

The base unit for mass quantities (kg). It is the only SI unit with a prefix as part of its name and symbol. The kilogram is equal to the mass of an international prototype in the form of a platinum-iridium cylinder kept at Sevres in France.
The base unit for length quantities (m). One meter was redefined in 1983 as the distance traveled by light in a vacuum in 1/299,792,458 of a second.
Equivalent to METRE (American spelling).
The base unit for amount of substance quantities (mol). The mole is the amount of substance of a system which contains as many elementary entities as there are atoms in 0.012 kilogram of carbon 12.

The base unit for duration quantities (s). It is defined as the duration of 9,192,631,770 cycles of radiation corresponding to the transition between two hyperfine levels of the ground state of cesium (1967 Standard).
The derived unit for mass quantities (g). The base unit for mass quantity is kilograms.
The unit for plane angle quantities (rad). One radian is the angle between two radii of a circle such that the length of the arc between them is equal to the radius.

The unit for solid angle quantities (sr). One steradian is the solid angle subtended at the center of a sphere by an area on the surface of the sphere that is equal to the radius squared. The total solid angle of a sphere is 4*Pi steradians.
The unit for binary information (bit).

The derived unit for frequency (Hz). A unit of frequency equal to one cycle per second. After Heinrich Rudolf Hertz (1857-1894), German physicist who was the first to produce radio waves artificially.

The derived unit for force (N). One newton is the force required to give a mass of 1 kilogram an Force of 1 metre per second per second. It is named after the English mathematician and physicist Sir Isaac Newton (1642-1727).
The derived unit for pressure, stress (Pa). One pascal is equal to one newton per square meter. It is named after the French philosopher and mathematician Blaise Pascal (1623-1662).

The derived unit for energy, work, quantity of heat (J). One joule is the amount of work done when an applied force of 1 newton moves through a distance of 1 metre in the direction of the force. It is named after the English physicist James Prescott Joule (1818-1889).
The derived unit for power, radiant, flux (W). One watt is equal to one joule per second. It is named after the British scientist James Watt (1736-1819).

The derived unit for electric charge, quantity of electricity (C). One Coulomb is equal to the quantity of charge transferred in one second by a steady current of one ampere. It is named after the French physicist Charles Augustin de Coulomb (1736-1806).

The derived unit for electric potential difference, electromotive force (V). One Volt is equal to the difference of electric potential between two points on a conducting wire carrying a constant current of one ampere when the power dissipated between the points is one watt. It is named after the Italian physicist Count Alessandro Volta (1745-1827).

The derived unit for capacitance (F). One Farad is equal to the capacitance of a capacitor having an equal and opposite charge of 1 coulomb on each plate and a potential difference of 1 volt between the plates. It is named after the British physicist and chemist Michael Faraday (1791-1867).

The derived unit for electric resistance (Ω or Ohm). One Ohm is equal to the resistance of a conductor in which a current of one ampere is produced by a potential of one volt across its terminals. It is named after the German physicist Georg Simon Ohm (1789-1854).
The derived unit for electric conductance (S). One Siemens is equal to one ampere per volt. It is named after the German engineer Ernst Werner von Siemens (1816-1892).

The derived unit for magnetic flux (Wb). One Weber is equal to the magnetic flux that in linking a circuit of one turn produces in it an electromotive force of one volt as it is uniformly reduced to zero within one second. It is named after the German physicist Wilhelm Eduard Weber (1804-1891).

The derived unit for magnetic flux density (T). One Tesla is equal equal to one weber per square meter. It is named after the Serbian-born American electrical engineer and physicist Nikola Tesla (1856-1943).

The derived unit for inductance (H). One Henry is equal to the inductance for which an induced electromotive force of one volt is produced when the current is varied at the rate of one ampere per second. It is named after the American physicist Joseph Henry (1791-1878).
The derived unit for Celsius temperature (℃). This is a unit of temperature such as the freezing point of water (at one atmosphere of pressure) is 0 ℃, while the boiling point is 100 ℃.
The derived unit for luminous flux (lm). One Lumen is equal to the amount of light given out through a solid angle by a source of one candela intensity radiating equally in all directions.
The derived unit for illuminance (lx). One Lux is equal to one lumen per square meter.

The derived unit for activity of a radionuclide (Bq). One becquerel is the radiation caused by one disintegration per second. It is named after the French physicist, Antoine-Henri Becquerel (1852-1908).

The derived unit for absorbed dose, specific energy (imparted), kerma (Gy). One gray is equal to the dose of one joule of energy absorbed per one kilogram of matter. It is named after the British physician L. H. Gray (1905-1965).

The derived unit for dose equivalent (Sv). One Sievert is equal is equal to the actual dose, in grays, multiplied by a "quality factor" which is larger for more dangerous forms of radiation. It is named after the Swedish physicist Rolf Sievert (1898-1966).
The derived unit for catalytic activity (kat).
The metric unit for velocity quantities (m/s).
The metric unit for acceleration quantities (m/s²).
The metric unit for area quantities (m²).
The metric unit for volume quantities (m³).
Equivalent to KILO(METRE).
Equivalent to CENTI(METRE).
Equivalent to MILLI(METRE).
